page.lettertext:
fol.194r
to the L: Chan
c
:
L Th
re
r &
L: Buckhurst
May it please yo
r
good LL
: as by o
r
former l
re
s we have
already signified, we delivered to the
States g
na
ll
upon the xvi
th
of June
last certaine Proposic
o
ns selected owt of the partes of o
r
Instructions, as
meetest in o
r
opinions to be first handled, in respect they did not onely
concerne the Reformac
o
n of the Disorders in the Musters and Martial
Discipline (whereof they have long Complayned) but also the matters
wherein her
Ma
tie
requireth satsifacc
o
n as by the Coppie sent herewith
shall best appeare unto yo
r
LL. Whereunto we received their answers
by way of Appostill the xiii
th
of July and not sooner, although
we were often importunate by speche and l
re
s to urge a conference
to thende we might come to some Conclusion uppon the said
Proposic
o
ns. After we had received and considered of their
answers, and founde the principall thing
required by her Ma
tie
w
th
gentle wordes denyed; we demanded audience and entred w
th
them into conference upon the xv
th
of this p
nt
e: shewed unto them
the reasons and Causes that mooved her Ma
tie
to demande the thing
they had denyed, and their inconsiderate refusall made to gratifie
her Ma
tie
in matters of so slender moment, and wherein she might
at all tymes right her self, having meanes thereunto as they
could conceive. This we amplified to the uttermost of o
r
understanding, and brought them to promise that they wolde
consider and deliberate againe upon the same point
, and yelde us
suche furder answere, as the state of their Country and affaires
wolde permitte.
Some fewe daies before the delivery of their Appostilles they
sent unto us in writing by their
Greffier
Aersens
, six Proposic
o
ns
by the w
ch
they desired to understande what auctoritie we had
to geve them satisfacc
o
n to the severall matters therein conteyned
whereunto we answered by way of Appostill as yo
r
LL. shall
perceyve by the inclosed.
But to digresse somewhat from these thing
we are to let yo
r
fol.194v
LL. understand that before we entred to Treate w
th
the States
upon the matters of o
r
Negotiac
o
n, we desired to knowe of
them, as we dyd at the tyme of o
r
first accesse, whether
they were auctorised from their Provinces to Treat and
Conclude w
th
us for thexplaining of the Treatie &c.
as we were from her Ma
tie
appearing by o
r
l
re
s of credence
delivered unto them: they answered us in so doubtfull maner
and w
th
such distinctions (standing upon the point
of their
Soveraintie and the absolute auctoritie they had in the
qualitie of the States g
na
ll) that we were constrained
to demaunde their answere in writing w
ch
yo
r
LL shall herew
th
receyve: They confessed nevertheles unto us that though
their auctoritie (as they were a Body) was sufficient to
deale and conclude in all thing
, yett in their Discretions they
ever used to have the advise of their particular Provinces
in all thing
that were to receive determinac
o
n among them
wherein they shold have cause to bynde the Provinces, and
that folowing the same course, they had imparted o
r
proposic
o
ns
to their severall Provinces and had geven answers unto them
according to the resoluc
o
ns they had receyved.
And furder concerning the Nine articles delivered unto them
by me Thomas Bodley in August last, they answered
in speche, that bycause the same conteyned onely g
na
lities
their Provinces coulde not agree to geve auctoritie to Treat
and Conclude upon them. for that their C
o
missions are
alwaies and onely geven upon thing
particular.
To returne to o
r
Conference when we had received their
answere as aforesaid, and put in some hope of better successe
after their seconde considerac
o
n had of o
r
Proposic
o
ns, we were
contented at their ernest request to open unto them how farre
we were auctorised to geve them satisfacc
o
n in the matters
of their six Proposic
o
ns, and dyd declare toching their Trade
w
th
fol.195r
Spaigne
that her Ma
tie
had geven us power to tender unto them
certaine condic
o
ns w
ch
her Ma
tie
required to have observed by the
subject
of the united Provinces trading to those partes: and for the
Disadvowance of the Actions of suche persons as they had pretended to
have disturbed their state under pretence of service to her Ma
tie
, [not]
had also here under her Ma
ts
hande an Acte or Declarac
o
n to that
effect. The States desired to have a Coppie of the Condic
o
ns
of their Trade, that they might consider of them, and we wolde
likewise deliver into their handes the Acte of Disadvowance to
thend they might use the same to the benefit of the Provinces
according to her Ma
ts
gracious purpose. And forasmuche as we
fynding them colde and slowe in satisfying (in any one pointe) her
Ma
ts
expectac
o
n, and desirous to geve them some provocac
o
n to proceede
roundly and breefly with us; we delivered unto them at o
r
third meeting
on the xvii
th
of this moneth a Coppy of the Condic
o
ns, and
yelded to let them see the Acte of Disadvowance.
The Condic
o
ns they misliked as overharde, alleaging that
their whole Trade into Eastlande was onely upon victuel,
Munition, and suche other Marchandises as were prohibited by
the said Condic
o
ns: That if they sholde forbeare to Trade
in those kyndes of Marchandise, other Nations wold prevent them
in the course of their Trafficq, and so their Trade and Navigac
o
n
decay to the ruine of their state.
The Acte of Disadvowance we refused to deliver (as so directed)
unles they wolde assent unto an abolition towarde such persons their Compatriot
as were banished and Disgraced by them for shewe of their affection to
do service to her Ma
tie
and her Nation in these Countries, and for
whome her Ma
tie
by her l
re
s and otherwise had often interceded
and could not prevayle. After long debating and many reasons
yelded by us to induce them to gratifie her Ma
tie
in this pointe
they Concluded that if we wolde deliver the Acte to be published
fol.195v
it wolde be a meane not onely to move the Provinces but
the Townes in particular where the banished
are
had
bene sentenced by course of Justice (and w
th
owt whose
consent they might not remitte th'offence already Judged)
to condescend to so muche as her Ma
tie
required. We
desired therein to be pardoned, and advised them on their
te
to bethinke themselves of a reciprocall course to gratifie
her Ma
tie
in the one, as she had freely and graciouslie
granted thother. But we founde not o
r
reasons and
perswasions at that tyme like to prevayle and so ended o
r
Conference.
Upon the xviij
th
of July we returned againe to o
r
audience expecting some gratefull answere to o
r
first
Proposic
o
ns, at w
ch
tyme
Barnevelt
(speaking for the
rest as President) declared unto us that the States
there assembled had w
th
good maturitie reviewed and
Considered o
r
Proposic
o
ns and that fynding a great
Difficultie in the fyrst article concerning the geving of
the Discipline and Publishing the Ordonnances for
Musters to her Ma
ts
auxiliarie Troupes w
ch
ap
teyning
unto them in respect of the Soveraintie of their Countries
they could not assent w
th
out prejudice to their auctoritie
that it shold be donne by her Ma
tie
, or in her name, and
that bycause the rest of the Articles required to be
granted were grounded upon the same matter and auctoritie
they might not in any sorte change their answeres already
geven: howbeit if we wolde deliver the reasons of o
r
mislike
of their said answeres in writing, they wold take some tyme
to consider furder on them, and use the advise of the
Councell
of State
how to geve us other satisfacc
o
n, although for
their owne partes they could not see how the p
nt
e state of their
fol.196r
Country could beare any other resolution to those point
then was
already delivered. True it is my LL that this first pointe
coming to be debated betwene them and us after their Appostilles
delivered, we stoode w
th
them, as warranted by the Contracte, (as
we take it) that her Ma
tie
and her G
na
l ought to geve the
Discipline to her owne subject
, in respect they were a voluntary
succo
r
of her Ma
tie
granted to the Provinces upon their humble
petic
o
n, and not as mercenarie though her Ma
t
charge were to
be remboursed at thende of their warres. They helde the
Troupes notw
th
standing to be mercenarie, and w
th
all pleaded
the last Article of the Treatie, where it is said that her
Ma
ts
Gouverno
r
and forces shall take the Oathe
accustomed
to
the Provinces, w
ch
, say they, is to Obey the discipline of
their Countryes. we therefore having in o
r
other Conferences
delivered asmuche as might in reason perswade them to allowe
this power to her Ma
tie
not thinking it fit to enter againe into
any furder dispute w
th
them of that matter, we tooke thoccasion
to replye to the last parte of their speeche, and declared
howmuche we wondred at their so strange and straight kynde
of dealing w
th
her Ma
tie
: howmuche they forgate the
benefitt
they had receved from her even to the preservac
o
n of their
Estate, That their maner of proceeding appeared unto us to be so full
of suspition and mistrust, that if we had bene Spaigniards it
coulde not be worse: That they were deceyved in their Conceipt
if they thought her Ma
tie
were not in case to mainteyne her
Estate w
th
owt them: That where they pretended their refusall
of her Ma
ts
Demaundes to be for the preservac
o
n of their
estate, that their course in this sorte helde towarde her Ma
tie
was a high way to the Ruine of the same: Yf her Ma
tie
be their ingratitude sholde be drawen to Revoke her succo
rs
:
That her Ma
ts
demaundes were not newe thing
unto them
but such as had bene often urged and ever denyed or doubtfully
fol.196v
answered: That it was not to be thought they were now to
seke of their resoluc
o
n to the said demandes, and that their
pretence to conferre w
th
the Councell or o
r
Replyes were
but devises to wynne tyme: and that we supposed the
Provinces not to be of their mindes, to yelde so ingratefull
requitall to her Ma
tie
for so greate and inestimable benefit
.
This, and muche more (too long to be written) we delivered
unto them, w
ch
bred in them no greate alterac
o
n of their
purpose, but rather a stomack to answere us, that they
were bounde to see to the saftye of their Countryes: That
these Demaundes of her Ma
tie
tended to the overthrowe
of them: That they knewe it dyd importe her
Ma
tie
asmuche as them to kepe their Countryes from
the Spaignard
, to whome if they sholde yelde
themselves by a Peace, her Ma
tie
wolde speedily
fynde the wante of their alliance: That whatsoever
her Ma
tie
had bestowed in the succo
r
of them according
to the Contracte, sholde be duely repaide, and for the
w
ch
sufficient Caution remained in her hands. and
that their resoluc
o
ns delivered to o
r
Demandes were
suche as they had receyved from their severall Provinces.
To these their answers we replyed as apperteyned, and
confirmed o
r
Conceipt
of their purpose even by their
owne doing
and allegac
o
ns. This Conference ended
we departed from their assembly w
th
out any Conclusion
at all, and w
th
as little hope of any better correspondence.
untill on the xix
th
of this moneth, one among them
professing himself in all dutie devoted to her Ma
tie
c
o
ming
to me Thomas Wilkes by occasion to my lodging fell into
speche of what had passed betwene the States and us
in the last Conference, gave me to understand as of
himself under of secrecie that upon some smalle considerac
o
n
taken by his Colleag
of the Proposic
o
ns upon the w
ch
fol.197r
we had somuche misliked, there was hope they wolde geve her Ma
tie
therein suche reasonable satisfacc
o
n as might well be required:
and therefore dyd advise us to proceede and to deliver againe in
writing suche reasons as we had uttered in spece to induce
them to yelde to her Ma
ts
demaunds. This party likewise
as a person seeming to tender her Ma
ts
hono
r
, and wishing a
good and dutifull opinion to be contynued in this people toward
her Ma
tie
, gave furder advise that we in seeking to procure
grace and remission for the banished and disgraced sholde
in any case forbeare to use her Ma
ts
name for suche as were
proscribed at
Leyden
, alleaging that forsomuche as the
late
Earle of Leycester
had disadvowed the dooing
of
those persons in that place, her Ma
tie
had no reason to
intreate for them, and that the motions heretofore made in
their favor from her Ma
tie
had geven some occa
o
n to suche
as were not well affected unto her, to enter into conceipte, and
to perswade others that her Ma
tie
shold take upon her to
advowe the dooing
of those men. He declared furder
that for all the rest (
Mons
r
Deventer
onely excepted) there
wolde be no difficultie made, and that likewise for her
Ma
ts
sake favo
r
might be granted to the men of
Leyden
so as sute were made by some particular person in their owne
names. By this advise we are incouraged to proceede
and to folowe the opinion and direction of the partie aforesaid
and upon the successe, will not faile w
th
diligence to
advertise yo
r
LLp.
Suche as have sought to disgrace and slander the
Actions of her Ma
tie
and her subject
here, have
dangerously blowen into the eares of the c
o
mon people that
her Ma
ts
intention from the begyning hath bin by indirect
and undue meanes (notw
th
standing her refusall made of the
Soveraintie and protection of these Countryes offered unto her)
to Seaze and usurpe the auctoritie and governm
t
in these contries
fol.197v
and to that ende whatsoever hath bin here don by her
Ma
ts
Generals that might receyve construction of evill,
is layde to her Ma
ts
Charge, as don by her Ma
tie
.
This hath bin spred by the practise of some notable
persons of these Countryes, suche as doo affect the faction
of the Frenche. W
ch
is folowed here (notw
th
standing
it is endevoured to perswade her Ma
tie
and yo
r
LL to the
contrary) so ernestly under hande, that the c
o
mon people
have nothing els in their mowthes and conceipt
but
that the
Frenche King
shall become their Soveraine
and stick not to say even to o
r
faces that are englishe that
they hope of better assistance and Relief from
France
then ever they have had from her Ma
tie
.
Moreover there is nothing don in
Englande
to the prejudice
of any inhabitante here, but is made matter to aggravate
and inlarge the misconceipt of the people against her
Ma
tie
, as namely some Ships and goodes of theirs nowe
lately staide by
S
r
Martin Frobosher
, (whereof at the
instance of the States we have written to yo
r
LL
) is geven
owt somuche to the disadvantage of her Ma
tie
and her
Nation as nothing more. We therefore aswell to [incontre]
this practise as to prevent the mischeefe that may folowe
thereof, have (as so advised from some of the best experienced
patriot
of these Countryes and under yo
r
LLp favor and correction)
thought good to frame a l
re
w
ch
her Ma
tie
by yo
r
LL
moc
o
n
and mediation may be pleased to write to certaine of the
principall Townes of the Provinces to stay the
slanderous report
and Conceipt
spred of her Ma
tie
as
aforesaid: the Coppie whereof yo
r
LL
shall receyve herew
th
to be altered and corrected as to you shalbe thought convenient
so it may answere the point
of the slander therein menc
o
ned
and a like draught of a l
re
to the States g
na
l notifyng
the Causes that have mooved her Ma
tie
in defence of
her hono
r
to write to the Townes, w
ch
we thinke as
fol.198r
necessarie as the other. wherein if there may be expedic
o
n used
we are opinion it will stay the violent course of the Practisers in
reguarde of France, Remoove all s inister Conceipt
here of her
Ma
tie
and her subject
, and drawe the Provinces to a better c
o
formitie
in the matters we have to propounde: Beseching yo
r
LL
nevertheles
(yf her Matie shalbe pleased to write the l
re
s) they may be sent
unto us and left to o
r
discretion to sende or use them, as we
shall fynde most convenient for her Ma
ts
service.
At the
Haghe
the xxij
th
of July. 1590.
